title: 115_hr257
content: The Act may be cited as the "Recognition of Jerusalem as the Capital of the State of Israel Act". Congress acknowledges the historical connection of the Jewish people to Israel and Jerusalem, the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948, the reunification of Jerusalem in 1967, and the disputed sovereignty claims over certain areas. In 1995, Congress approved the Jerusalem Embassy Act, requiring the US Embassy to be established in Jerusalem by May 31, 1999. Israel has exceeded international law regulations in ensuring public order and safety in Jerusalem, making it safer than under previous authorities. Civil life thrives in Jerusalem under Israel's administration. The government institutions in Jerusalem include the Knesset, Bank of Israel, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Prime Minister's and President's offices, and the Supreme Court. Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and relocation of the US embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. The United States policy is to recognize Jerusalem as the undivided capital of Israel, both de jure and de facto. Congress believes that the US should acknowledge Jerusalem as Israel's capital, move the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, affirm Jerusalem as Israel's capital publicly, implement the Jerusalem Embassy Act, and adhere to US law on this matter. The United States policy is to recognize Jerusalem as the undivided capital of Israel. Any official US Government document listing countries and their capitals must identify Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The President must relocate the US Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem by January 1, 2019. The Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995 is amended by repealing section 7 and redesignating section 8 as section 7. The repeal will take effect on January 1, 2018. Additionally, there is a requirement for an implementation report. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the Act's enactment detailing the plan to establish the US Embassy in Jerusalem, including estimated completion dates and funding requirements.
